```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
library(tidyverse)
library(knitr)
beetle_data<-read_csv("Data/beetle_data.csv")
```

# A Large Heading

## A smaller heading

### A bit smaller heading

#### A much smaller heading

This report uses the **tidyverse** package along with the *beetle_data* dataset, which has columns including:

-   counts
-   Tmax
-   dist_to_edge

You can insert line breaks like this. <br> and they should work.

<br> You can define paragraphs like this:

<p>

This is the topic sentence of my paragraph. Now I move to my second sentence which is on topic but a bit more specific.

<p/>

<p>Let's start a new paragraph. This is a short one.</p>

<br> If you don't like using paragraphs, you can just use line breaks and get a similar effect. <br><br>

# R code

You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r}
summary(beetle_data)
```

You can suppress the R code being printed in the HTML like this:

```{r, echo=F}
summary(beetle_data)
```

You can suppress the summary being printed in the HTML like this:

```{r, eval=F}
summary(beetle_data)
```

To include a nice grey line between sections, just use:

------------------------------------------------------------------------

# Including Plots

You can embed plots, for example:

```{r, echo=F}
with(beetle_data, plot(counts ~ Tmax))
```

## now John is showing off

You can specify the size and justification of r plots like this, as well as add a caption:

```{r, echo=F, fig.align="center", fig.width=6, fig.height=6, fig.cap="Figure 1: Here is the same plot with solid salmon points."}
with(beetle_data, plot(counts ~ Tmax, col="salmon", pch=16))
```

# Add an equation

::: {style="text-align: center; font-size: 25pt;"}
$t = \frac{m - \mu}{s /\sqrt n}$
:::

$m$ is the sample mean;<br> $\mu$ is the "population" mean (a hypothetical value that you're testing against);<br> $s$ is the standard deviation;<br> $n$ is the sample size.
